Prices As Low As Anywhere in City.

Book Prices Due To Sudden Changes.

The NEWS-LETTER has been carrying on an investigation for the
purpose of getting at the bottom
of the justice of recent complaints
against the • bookstore on the
grounds of overcharges for books
and stationery. After a careful
comparison of prices charged at
the university store and those
asked by leading downtown concerns, it is evident that the complaints are unfounded and that
downtown figures are as large, and
in some cases considerably larger
than those charged at the university.
As concerns stationery, one article for which students considered
themselves overcharged was the
Venus drawing pencil. The price
of this pencil is 10 cents at the
university, and nowhere down
town, so far as is known, can it be
obtained for less. All notebook
paper, which is now selling for 12
cents a package at the bookstore,
is 15 cents at a number of stores
in the city. Thus Hopkins students are actually getting their
Paper cheaper than would be possible elsewhere. The quality of
the paper and the size of the packages are the same at all places.
As regards the S. P. cardboard
notebooks prices vary greatly. The
smaller sizes which sell for 55 and
35 cents at the bookstore are the
same down town, but the larger
sized books can be bought for from
5 to 10 cents less at one dealers,
while prices at other stores are
considerably higher than bookstore quotations.

text book was less expensive in
town than at the university. The
great majority of books sell for
the same price everywhere, and
many instances were found where
13 to 18 per cent. can be saved
by buying books at the bookstore.

SPRING COMPETITION FOR EDITORIAL BOARD TO
START WEDNESDAY.
-Open to All Students at University—Judged Strictly on Merit.

The spring competition for the Editorial Board of the. NEWSLETTER will start Wednesday, February 16. All candidates should
attend the meeting to be held at 12.30 in the NEWS-LETTER office
in the Barn.
The competition will be judged on the basis of neatness, punctuality, style, accuracy and amount of "copy" submitted, and election to the board as Junior Editor will depend strictly on merit.
It is hoped that a large number of students, but especially freshmen, will compete, since the larger the number, the greater will
be the ability of those chosen.

GENERALS NOSE OUT
BLACK AND BLUE CAGEMEN IN LAST FEW
MINUTES OF PLAY.
Large Audience Present—New Men
on Squad—Freshmen Defeat Second Team in Preliminary
Game.

Hopkins was nosed out by the
Washington and Lee basket-ball
team in the Fifth Regiment
Armory Friday night in the closing minutes of one of the hardest
fought games seen here this year
by the score of 29 to 24. With
Stevens, the star guard, shooting
baskets at odd times from the middle of the floor, the Washington
and Lee team kept pace with the
Black and Blue tossers until near
the close of the first half, when
spectacular shots by Wood and
Wilson gave the Hopkins five a
lead of 5 points, the period ending
with the score 16 to 11.
The game was close and interesting from start to finish, each team
fighting its hardest to gain or to
keep the lead. The score seesawed back and forth on fouls and
pretty shots; in the second half
the score was tied three times,
with Hopkins always scoring first
and taking the lead, which brought
forth much cheering.
Hopkins gave an excellent exhibition of team work and fighting
spirit, and with, as a result of
the Black List, a number of new
additions to the • squad put up a
better game than even the most
optimistic had counted on. Bill
Wood, Keye, Wilson and Wilkinson showed up well—in fact, the
entire team played excellently, and
should give Lehigh a hard tussle
in their contest here next Friday.
One of the added features was
the music furnished by the Hopkins Undergraduate Orchestra, directed very ably by "Mike" Bowers. The music was all up to date
and well played. By far the largest crowd to witness a game this
season was on hand, and many
stayed to enjoy the dancing.
Baltimore Polytechnic team did
not appear for its scheduled game
with the Freshmen, so the Freshmen first team played the second
team, which they defeated by a
21 to 8 score. Marchetti played a
stellar game and proved to be a
consistent point-maker.

EDMUND SPIEKER, '16, BECOMES DIRECTOR OF
GLEE CLUB

TOME
SCHOOL
TURNS

Was Member For Four Years—Cut
Down Size of Club For Concerts.
More Candidates Desired—Jazz

The Glee Club jias been fortunate enough to secure as its director for the rest of the year a
man of marked musical ability
and one who has had former experience in leading a college musical organization. Mr. Edmund M.
Spieker, '16, was for four years a
member of the Hopkins combined
musical clubs, their president in
1916 and their leader for the two
years following. Reorganization
immediately followed the installation of the new director at last
Tuesday's Glee Club practice. The
size of the club is being cut down
for concert purposes so as to get
only the best voices, but the number of men out for the club, it has
been announced, should be increased. Especially are second
bases needed.
The jazz orchestra has been
working hard to get the latest
popular pieces ."down pat." It
played for the dance at the Fifth
Regiment Armory on February 11
with great success and will play
again for the Dramatic Club production of "Arms and the Man"
on March 11. As now arranged it
consists of Bowers (leader), Vanneman, Campbell, Shaffer, Coulter,
Feldman and Sader.
Manager Hubbard has arranged
the following concerts for the
spring term:
March 16—Harlem Park Methodist Episcopal Church.
March 18 — State Normal
School (pending).
April 8—Eastern High School
(pending).
April 15—Goucher College.
The combined clubs may also
take a trip to Hood College and
the home concert will probably
be held the first week in May.

ANOTHER CLUB ADDED TO.
LONG LIST OF HOPKINS
ACTIVITIES
"Cane Club" Founded With 14 Members—Juniors and Seniors To
Be Admitted.

About three weeks ago several
men of the university who usually
may be found at odd times in the
"Barn" met together and organized a novel club which to the
outside world is to be known as
the "Cane Club." Perhaps you've
seen Elmer Jones or Norman
Keyes limping around with a cane
and thought that natural, but
when Bartus Trew came out with
his folding walking stick which he
can put in his pocket, and Kennady and Waters began using
canes there seemed to be some attempt in view to renew an old Hopkins tradition. But this "Cane
Club" is not an old Hopkins tradition, it is a new organization the
14 founders of which desire that it
be continued by succeeding classes
and therefore are going to take
Juniors in as well as Seniors. To
be eligible an undergraduate must
also have done something of note
around the university. It is an association of good fellows who on
meeting days must appear with
their canes, and the rest of the
time wear a small emblem on their
watch chains.

The last meeting of the Varsity
Club was held on Monday, February 7 at the Johns Hopkins Club.
Though the notices read 8 o'clock
it was not until nearly 9 o'clock
that a quorum arrived and business began. The regular order of
business was short but very important. Two amendments to the
constitution on which had been
suggested at the previous meeting
were passed upon and unanimously adopted. The first makes undergraduates winning an "H" eligible
for membership in the club and if
elected allows them to become
members upon payment of an initiation fee of $2. They will be, however, without the power to vote on
any matter connected with undergraduate athletics, so that these
men will be present at the meetings and will be able to give firsthand information and opinions
which will assist the older members in directing the policy in accord with the undergraduate viewpoint. All undergraduates become
full members upon severing their
connection with the university
without the payment of further
fees. The second provides that the
annual meeting shall be held in
June of each year instead of November; accordingly one set of officers and committees will hold office for a whole academic year.
This change of date of election prevents an abrupt break in the middle of a season and gives each committee a chance to work out the
plans that it has formulated.
Following the passage of these
two amendments there was an informal discussion about the prospects in lacrosse and track, especially the Fifth Regiment Armory
meet for the coming season.
Mr. Frank LeMott, chairman of
the Students' Occupation Committee, reported that he had found
several stores which would permit
students to act as part-time salesmen for them. Several men who
are being helped through college
by the club have already been assigned to these positions.
The
whole-hearted co-operation of the
student-body is desired in helping
these men to work their way
through college.
Initiation will be held in the
spring, when a regular old-fashioned "tap-day" will take place.
Such a day will be long remembered by the man who is notified
of his election and by the on-looking student-body.
The charter members are: Jones,
Keyes, Lovell, Trew, Cashell,
Waters, Kennady, Griffiss, Turner,
Wells, Engel, Morgan and Marken.

AN UNJUST ACCUSATION.
Too much censure cannot be imposed upon those who posted in
the postoffice the charges against
the bookstore just before examinations. Although subsequent investigation has proved the charges
false, they are bound to influence
the trade of the student body.
It is not only the falseness of
the charges, but the manner in
which they were made which
should be condemned. Such a
method of attack is unfair. If the
men who made the charges honestly believed them, why did they
not come out in the open and say
so? Instead of that they signed it
"Senior Class" and various other
scholastic classes without, as we
have found later, the slightest authority for such action. As a result, the placard had far greater
influence than it would otherwise
have had.
No charges of such a serious
nature should be made without the
most thorough consideration, nor
should they be made in such a
manner. They should be brought
to the attention of the Student
Council and be laid by them before
the dean.
If the men who put up the placard are able to prove their statements, we ask them in this case to
bring the proof to us, as we have
the promise of the dean to act if
such charges are justified.

LONG LIST OF HOPKINS
ACTIVITIES
"Cane Club" Founded With 14 Members—Juniors and Seniors To
Be Admitted.

About three weeks ago several
men of the university who usually
may be found at odd times in the
"Barn" met together and organized a novel club which to the
outside world is to be known as
the "Cane Club." Perhaps you've
seen Elmer Jones or Norman
Keyes limping around with a cane
and thought that natural, but
when Bartus Trew came out with
his folding walking stick which he
can put in his pocket, and Kennady and Waters began using
canes there seemed to be some attempt in view to renew an old Hopkins tradition. But this "Cane
Club" is not an old Hopkins tradition, it is a new organization the
14 founders of which desire that it
be continued by succeeding classes
and therefore are going to take
Juniors in as well as Seniors. To
be eligible an undergraduate must
also have done something of note
around the university. It is an association of good fellows who on
meeting days must appear with
their canes, and the rest of the
time wear a small emblem on their
watch chains.

The last meeting of the Varsity
Club was held on Monday, February 7 at the Johns Hopkins Club.
Though the notices read 8 o'clock
it was not until nearly 9 o'clock
that a quorum arrived and business began. The regular order of
business was short but very important. Two amendments to the
constitution on which had been
suggested at the previous meeting
were passed upon and unanimously adopted. The first makes undergraduates winning an "H" eligible
for membership in the club and if
elected allows them to become
members upon payment of an initiation fee of $2. They will be, however, without the power to vote on
any matter connected with undergraduate athletics, so that these
men will be present at the meetings and will be able to give firsthand information and opinions
which will assist the older members in directing the policy in accord with the undergraduate viewpoint. All undergraduates become
full members upon severing their
connection with the university
without the payment of further
fees. The second provides that the
annual meeting shall be held in
June of each year instead of November; accordingly one set of officers and committees will hold office for a whole academic year.
This change of date of election prevents an abrupt break in the middle of a season and gives each committee a chance to work out the
plans that it has formulated.
Following the passage of these
two amendments there was an informal discussion about the prospects in lacrosse and track, especially the Fifth Regiment Armory
meet for the coming season.
Mr. Frank LeMott, chairman of
the Students' Occupation Committee, reported that he had found
several stores which would permit
students to act as part-time salesmen for them. Several men who
are being helped through college
by the club have already been assigned to these positions.
The
whole-hearted co-operation of the
student-body is desired in helping
these men to work their way
through college.
Initiation will be held in the
spring, when a regular old-fashioned "tap-day" will take place.
Such a day will be long remembered by the man who is notified
of his election and by the on-looking student-body.
The charter members are: Jones,
Keyes, Lovell, Trew, Cashell,
Waters, Kennady, Griffiss, Turner,
Wells, Engel, Morgan and Marken.

The annual convention of the
Omicron Delta Kappa Fraternity
was held on Saturday, February 5,
in the Graham Lee Literary Club,
Washington and Lee University,
Lexington, Va. Dr. French, the
national president;Norman Keyes;
'21, and T. T. Burger, a member of
the executive council, were the
delegates from the Johns Hopkins
Circle.
Busittess session were held 10.30

publig initiation and delivered a
most interesting address on "Selective Education." A new circle

of Richmond and plans made for

University of Pittsburgh.

unanimously re-elected: Dr. John
C. French of Johns Hopkins, president; Dr. McConnell of Davidson

Fisher of Washington and Lee, secretary; William R. Brown of
Washington and Lee, treasurer.

be given 20 minutes to use in what
manner he pleases, that is, either
